ast.name: bubble popper tutorial
ast.comment: A tutorial to build a bubble popper game from scratch. #docs #tutorials #games

body.text: In this tutorial you will learn how to build a bubble popper game.
* good and bad bubbles fall down from the top of the screen
* the player gets points for tapping a good bubble; the good bubble disappears when tapped
* the player looses a life when tapping a bad bubble;
* as time goes, there starts to be more bad bubble and their speed start to vary
Let's turn those rules into a game!
* open a browser and go to [touchdevelop.com/app](http://touchdevelop.com/app)
* tap **Create Script** and select the **bubble popper** template
The template comes with the code to setup a game engine and move objects using physics.
* in the `main` action, a [board](/gameboard) is created and displayed on the screen
* in the `gameloop` event, the physics are _evolved_ and the board is redrawn on the wall.

Since we are going to deal with a large number of bubble sprites, we want to organize them in groups. The `board` provides the ability to create a [sprite set](/SpriteSet) which represents a collection of sprites. A sprite set lets you do all kinds of operations on multiple sprites at once. This is exactly what we need.
So let's create a sprite set and store it into a `data` variable. `data` variables are global and can be accessed from any action or event.
* tap on the last line of code
* tap on the bottom `[+]` button to add a new line
* tap on `sprites` and tap on the `[rename]` button
* tap on ``good bubbles`` and tap on the `[promote to data]` button

Now that we have the `data->good bubbles` sprite set, let's add a bunch of bubbles into it. Instead of typing the same code over and over again for each bubble, we are going to use a [](/for) loop to do this repetitive work.
* select the `for` statement in the blue keyboard
* let's start with 10 bubbles so add ``10`` where the `...` are
* **in the for loop**, add a line of code to create a picture sprite
* type **bubble**, pick one of the bubble image
* tap `store in var` to store the sprite into a local variable
* add a new line in the `for` loop
* tap on `add` and the editor should automatically insert `good bubbles` as the argument.
* try to run your game and see what happens
Oh no! The bubbles are all in the center and they all fall down together. Let's scatter the bubble all over the screen using `math->random range`.
* **in the for loop**, compute 2 random numbers for the `x` and `y` position of the bubble
* use `set pos` to set the position of the good bubble
* try to run your game and see what happens
Oh no! The bubble are not moving!
The bubbles are not moving because there are no forces applied to them and they have no initial speed. Let's set they vertical speed (`speed y`) while creating them in the loop.
* **in the for loop,** set the **speed y** of ``good bubble`` to 150
* set the width of `good bubble` to 100 as the image might be too big
* try the game and see what happens
* use `math->random range` and `set width` to create bubble of different sizes
Oh no! The bubble fall off the screen and never come back!

We want to create the effect that an infinite amount of bubbles is falling from the top of screen. Rather than creating more and more bubbles, we can simply re-position the bubbles that fell off the bottom of the screen to the top.
If we had to break down this task into a sentence, it could look like this:
> _for each_ good bubble, _if off screen_ then _move to top_
This sentence above almost reads like code, it is commonly called pseudo-code. Let's translate it into real code.
* add a new line and select **for each**
The [for each](/foreach) loop will run the code nested for each good bubble in the set.

The next step is to detect if a good bubble is off screen using an [](/if) statement. We can easily do that by using its `y` coordinate. Remember that the vertical coordinates are inverted and the origin is the top-left corner of the screen.
* **in the for each**, add an `if` statement to test if the sprite is off the screen
Once we detected that a good bubble is off screen, we can use `set pos` to re-position it at the top of the screen. We also use `math->random range` to move it horizontally.
* **in the for each**, add the code to position the sprite on top of the screen
* try run the game and see what happens
The game is starting to shape. Let's make it more fun by adding a background picture.
* try your game and see what happens
Let's add a little popping sound whenever a bubble leaves the screen.
* **in the if inside of the for each**, add a new line
* try to run your game and see what happens

Now that the bubbles are happily falling down the screen, we can work on popping them! To do so, we must add code that runs when the user taps one of them. Fortunately, this is pretty easy as we can register an _tap_ event to `data->good bubbles` sprite set.
* select **tap sprite in good bubbles** and the editor should display the following code

The `tap sprite in good bubbles` event will be called whenever the user taps on a sprite that is part of the `data->good bubbles` sprite set. Let's start by re-positioning the bubble when it gets tapped.
* **go to tap sprite in good bubbles**
* play a sound when popping a bubble
Each time a bubble is popped, the user should receive some points. Let's start by keeping track of the score using a `data-> data` variable.
* rename the variable to `score` and promote it to `data`
* **go to tap sprite in good bubbles**
* add a new line and increment the score
We want to show the score to the user at all time. We will need to create a text sprite, position it into a corner of the screen and update its text each time we change the score.
* create a new text sprite and store it in a variable
* rename `sprite` to `score sprite` and promote it
* position it on the upper left corner
* add new line to update the text. The text "score: " and the score are glued together using the || symbol.
Adding bad bubbles is very similar to the good bubbles. You need to create a new [sprite set](/spriteset), add the bad bubbles in a [](/for) loop and handle the `tap` event.
